content.content: MIP75c3-SP1: Onboard Task Force - Growth Task Force  Preamble MIP75c3-SP#: 1 Title: Onboard Task Force - Growth Task Force Author(s): Sam MacPherson (@hexonaut) Contributors: Tags: task-force growth-task-force Status: Rejected Date Proposed: 2022-05-01 Date Ratified: 2022-06-27 Ratification Poll URL: N/A Forum URL: https://forum.makerdao.com/t/mip75c3-sp1-onboard-task-force-growth-task-force/15094 Ratification Poll URL: https://vote.makerdao.com/polling/Qmbs5Kx5   Specification   Name: Growth Task Force  Members:  Sam MacPherson (@hexonaut) - Technical Nadia Alvarez (@nadia) - Business Development Mariano Di Pietrantonio (@MarianoDP) - Brand Mark Phillips (@aes) - Finance Adrian Cachinero Vasiljevic (@adcv) - Finance Sébastien Derivaux (@SebVentures) - Finance Luca Prosperi (@luca_pro) - Lending Oversight TJ Ragsdale (@teej) - Real World Assets Niklas Kunkel (@NikKunkel) - Business Strategy    Requested Initial Funding: 1m DAI  Multi-sig Address (7-of-9): TODO   Mandate The Growth Task Force aims to grow the Maker ecosystem as fast as possible. It is our view that we are in a nascent stage of crypto, and controlling as much future market share as possible is critical for the survival of this project. Our focus is on practical solutions to achieve the objectives listed below as quickly as possible. Perfection is the enemy of progress. We aim to find solutions that work first and backfill decentralization / resilience later.  Short Term Objectives  Capital raise to solve cash flow problems and increase surplus buffer to improve risk tolerance. This may be done through a combination of equity and debt instruments. Multi-chain expansion to grow our user base with a focus on meeting retail users where they are/going to be. This includes boosting DAI liquidity on as many chains as possible. Positioning Maker as a credit wholesaler from which third parties can get access to durable, affordable credit. Start earning interest on the stablecoin supply with short-term treasuries and other low-risk strategies. A focus on enabling the DAO to hire and retain talent via initiatives such as conference and hackathon sponsorships.   Long Term Objectives  Grow the interest-bearing DAI supply such that we can re-activate the Dai Savings Rate. Marketing DAI as the sustainable stablecoin that gives you an implicit savings rate. Fly-wheel growth via higher DSR → More DAI Demand → More Capacity for Loans → Sustain the DSR.   Anticipated Spends: Fundraising Roadshow & Promotion  Conference sponsorship to get speaker access. This will allow us to deliver keynotes, guide hackathons, etc. This will help us both on the hiring as well as the partnership front. DAO-wide offsite in late summer with training sessions from core units, talks, activities in an effort to align the DAO on long term objectives. This will foster trust and community within the DAO. Hire a lawyer to review possible capital raise structures Any other ad-hoc expense that is useful and cannot be covered by the scope of individual core units.  Please note the associated fund is a request for delegated authority to spend in a discretionary way to help meet the objectives of the Task Force. It’s entirely possible this fund goes unused, but it is our preference to have it available and not use it rather than being unable to execute on something due to governance overhead.

The proposal outlines the short and long-term objectives of the task force, including fundraising, multi-chain expansion, and marketing DAI as a sustainable stablecoin. The author explains the mandate of the task force and the anticipated spends, while also welcoming feedback and collaboration from third parties. The post receives entirely positive feedback from third parties, but also includes constructive criticism and suggestions for improvement.

content.content: Thanks for the constructive feedback @ACREinvest and @williamr. First I agree that CU members are already informally working on these tasks. Often in negotiations we need to have the authority to make agreements and credible threats. We cannot effectively do this if we have no formal mandate to be negotiating on behalf of the DAO. This proposal mostly formalizes this, such that the DAO says okay go ahead you can come to arrangements with the DAO’s counter-parties and communicate the proposals to the delegates to see if it’s desirable. The current system continues the negotiation phase into the forum where counter-parties are able to get concessions due to the non-uniform stance of the DAO. This is largely to our disadvantage and sometimes means we cannot arrange things at all as sometimes deals span many different aspects. Sometimes MakerDAO may have leverage that the counter-party is unaware of and broadcasting the details of that leverage in a public setting completely defeats the point as they are now aware. This is why we need private negotiations otherwise we just cannot achieve anything of practical use. Working groups also exist, but serve a more narrow purpose as you say and are unelected. This is a bit broader and saves the overhead of having to go to governance for every initiative. For me I’d much rather be spending my time working on delivering MCD on L2, D3Ms, striking deals, etc instead of on the forum. I don’t think this proposal is going too far as there is still the public MIPs process where anything over the top or malicious can be opposed. Does this answer everything?

content.content: Hmm, I understand request for flexibility but the way I think of pay is that each person is paid some annual salary to work for the betterment of the protocol.  If we need flexibility in the mandates to allow for work across core units, let’s talk about that.  But why do we need extra funds to do that?  Are people getting paid more to work functions that aren’t specific to their CU?  Do you get extra money on top of what you are being paid for being part of a working group?  That would essentially equate to asking for a raise.  I think that’s the part that isn’t going over too well…especially in a down market where DAI demand is down and MKR recurring revenue is slowly going down.  The margins are much thinner and there’s much less money to fling around.  Maybe one way to better present this request is to somehow exclude use of funds for personal benefit of participating members. MKR has performed very well but it doesn’t seem like the time to start spending more.  If anything, the downfall of terra gives the protocol more time to figure things out and get things right.  Going down the path toward unprofitability takes that luxury away and puts us in a more precarious position. What we really want is to be able to trust that CU members are not working for their own benefit more than the protocol’s benefit.  That they can work harder and smarter without continuing to ask for more so that we can all benefit together rather than feeling like we’re all competing for a piece of the pie.

content.content: Traster_Tray:  What we really want is to be able to trust that CU members are not working for their own benefit more than the protocol’s benefit.   Since we cannot “see” what work is being performed that adds value to the protocol, maybe a better way of coordinating would be to use something like coordinape. MKR holders vote on the number of points allocated to each recognized delegate. The delegate gives these points to contributors of the protocol, but cannot reward themselves. Points are redeemed for DAI. This system puts delegates in charge of paying other contributors for their proof of (off-chain) work while developing (on-chain) reputation. If a delegate stops accruing points or is accruing way too many, then they can have their role revoked and a new member added as a recognized delegate. This creates a decentralized workforce with some checks and balances through retroactive funding of labor already performed and trust in fellow Maker contributors.

content.content: The poll is ternary so you can approve the Task Force without the budget.

Personally, I have attended multiple conferences on my own dime and intend on attending others this summer via self-funding. So, I do understand why other here on this thread are concern and feel like a $1M ask is unjustified, when Core Units have their own budgets and folks like myself and others are compensated via the Surplus Buffer. You couple that with the current economic environment and I think you and the others in this committee, should understand why this is a tough pill to swallow for many. With that in mind—Let’s do a breakdown of the short-term initiative (after all the community is going to think “short-term” = fast results)     hexonaut:  Capital raise to solve cash flow problems and increase surplus buffer to improve risk tolerance. This may be done through a combination of equity and debt instruments.   Is it fair to say that meeting with interested parties (folks looking to put capital to work) can be done while attending a conference? I imagine that the majority of the expense will come from hiring firms for Legal work/review. If so, I think early-on your proposal should have stated such. But even then, legal reviews/M&A/deal structuring fees can run somewhere around $150k-$300K. This alone can eat up to 30% of the budget ask. Wouldn’t it make sense to do a SPF (MIP55) assuming MKR token holders approve a capital raise ?     hexonaut:  Multi-chain expansion to grow our user base with a focus on meeting retail users where they are/going to be. This includes boosting DAI liquidity on as many chains as possible.   I imagine the majority of the expense here comes from audits, perhaps outsourcing some of the work to other CU team members (they’ll need to be compensated), etc.—wouldn’t it be clever here to ask some of these chains to incentivize MKR token owners to make such a move? In other words, perhaps asking someone like Polygon to make an investment in the MakerDAO ecosystem? Or, ask them to fund such initiative?(thinking of ways where money can be saved)     hexonaut:  Positioning Maker as a credit wholesaler from which third parties can get access to durable, affordable credit.   Playing devils advocate here—Correct me if I am wrong, but I think this is already part of the mandate for the Growth CU? I imagine their current and the next budget should support initiatives (business development) correlated to positioning Maker as a wholesaler of credit via Maker Vaults? Please expand—perhaps I’m misunderstanding.     hexonaut:  Start earning interest on the stablecoin supply with short-term treasuries and other low-risk strategies.   This sounds similar to MIP65, and there’s also MIP72, can you please expand further on how this differs? From the outside looking in, the community might think you’re preaching the same gospel.     hexonaut:  A focus on enabling the DAO to hire and retain talent via initiatives such as conference and hackathon sponsorships.   While I agree that hackathons are super necessary and desperately needed, if you search in this forum for “hackathon” — there have been many budget proposals to do such by teams ranging from the Growth CU, to Data Insights, to the Oracles CU, etc. — looking from the outside-in, one would think this is already a mandate by many Core Units. Can you please expand on why  this task-force can make hackathons come into fruition more efficiently? Thanks in advance—trying to see the playing field from the community’s point of view.

content.content: hexonaut:  Heads up, we’ve added “Hire a lawyer to review possible capital raise structures” as a likely Growth Task Force expense.   I am curious how a law firm can advise on the capital raise because MakerDAO is not a legal person. Attorneys must have a “client” to represent. It’s a topic I have discussed with several peers and herein is a difficult reality we face. Who would be the client when attempting to engage counsel for the capital raise? Lawyers also are very mindful of who can rely on their advice. What’s in the best interest of one MKR holder vs another, or a Core Unit or Delegate… each has a particular situation and set of risks/benefits in any scenario. I’d be extremely caution of any firm claiming they can give overall advice about what the DAO should do. I further suggest before allocating any budget for such legal costs, there first should be a governance vote approving some scope of what the capital raise deal would look like, or several alternatives to evaluate. A lawyer is not going to be able to give any useful advice (even if the client issue is solved) without certain facts specified. It would be imprudent to pay hefty fees advising on various structures before narrowing the high-level scope via community consensus. Overall, I’m still leaning against supporting this. I’d like to see the relevant CU mandates and budget line items amended as needed instead to address the additional flexibility you need to coordinate, and that any budget implications follow the established control process.

psychonaut:  Can this simultaneously be submitted as a MIP55 SPF subproposal in case MIP75 is rejected?   To respond to this specifically, I’m not sure the SPF process is suitable for what this proposal intends to achieve. By definition:  A Special Purpose Fund (SPF) is used to fulfil a narrow, specific, or temporary objective  By design, Task Forces have the freedom to make their own business decisions and set their own objectives without needing as much Governance oversight. This wouldn’t be achievable through the current SPF framework as it doesn’t meet the requirements, they are not narrow, specific, or temporary in nature. That said, specific proposals that the Growth Task Force wanted to submit to MKR holders may be suitable for the SPF framework, in isolation.  E.g. an SPF to get a legal opinion on a specific action as part of an overall growth strategy.
